hobby.message: You still tuning those antique typewriters?
Freestyle FPV drones still keeping you sane?
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Hm. Still dry, yes. Suits me fine.
Keeps ink from smudging when I'm writing.
I restore old typewriters. Quiet hobby, doesn't bother anyone.
Lately, even that's felt a bit exposed.
Dry enough for paper work, at least.
I've been restoring an old Olivetti. Typewriters, you know.
Keeps me busy when things above ground are unsettled.
Crowds below my window lately make it harder to focus.
People notice everything these days, even the sound of a ribbon.
Dry, thankfully. Good weather for working on typewriters—my main hobby.
Spent the afternoon adjusting the carriage on a Lettera 32.
Used to get lost in the sound of the keys.
Now, with everyone talking about Halden Echoes outside, I get distracted.
Feels like the city's gotten noisier, less private.
Still, old machines have patience, even if the world doesn't.
Dry as ever. Enough for me to polish up an old Underwood.
Restoring typewriters is my thing. Vintage keys, carbon ribbons, all of it.
Today the noise from the square almost had me replacing the ribbon twice.
People were reading out the Halden Echoes replies right outside my door.
It's odd—typing used to be the most private act, now it feels watched.
I keep a written journal too. Safer than the terminals, I think.
Recent days have me second-guessing even that.
Dry, which I take as a blessing for careful work with ink and machines.
Most people don't know—I've restored over a dozen typewriters, some from before the first biometric census.
It's how I keep memories straight. I type, then hand-write my real thoughts.
Crowds out front, arguing over the latest oracle answers, threw off my process tonight.
Not long ago, you could trust the square to be quiet after dusk.
Now, every word put to paper feels like it needs a system clearance.
Funny. Paper outlasts any profile, if you hide it well enough.
Sometimes I think these machines are the last things out of the system's reach.
hobby_answer: You could say that. Typewriters don't judge.
Less fuss than most machines these days.
My Olivetti still works if I keep it quiet.
Crowds outside lately make it hard to focus.
Too much interest in old hobbies since the Echoes began.
Typewriters work. People, well, not always so predictable.
Old habits are safest written, not spoken.
Evenings used to be better for it, before those street crowds.
Funny how even paper feels less private now.
I keep sessions brief when that oracle crowd gathers.
Hard to ignore the way words travel, even from a typewriter.
Yes, typewriters have outlasted most things I trust.
Restoring them clears the mind, or did until lately.
Since the Halden Echoes crowds started, evenings are different.
Harder to write when every sound carries up from below.
Their debates drift up—makes focusing on words tough.
Sometimes feels like even my keypresses are public.
It’s a small thing, but privacy feels thinner now.
Definitely—typewriters don’t flag errors across the city.
Restoration’s ritual for me. Breathing space from system routines.
Now, with Echoes broadcasts, it’s harder to lose myself in it.
The square below fills up, voices about truth and hiding things.
Last week, I mistyped three lines, distracted by their talk.
Had to remind myself who I was really writing for.
Typewriting now feels exposed, like anything could be overheard.
It stirs memories—who can really say what’s private these days?
Better than people, and more honest. Each machine has memory—like its own story.
Learned early that written words outlast spoken ones. My habit became protection.
I used to type for hours, undisturbed, journaling when no one listened.
After Halden’s death, and now with the Echoes, my window’s never quiet.
Crowds debate outside—talk of secrets, truth, every sound carries to my study.
Sometimes I pause, hands off keys, listening for risk in their words.
Last week, I nearly stopped mid-entry. Felt like being read over my shoulder.
Even these simple rituals are marked. The city’s mood seeps in.
If you restore old things, you feel change first—before it becomes official.
